section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Literacy: Read-Aloud Comprehension; Alphabet Knowledge; Phonological Awareness

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about the alphabet letters Gg, Dd, and Uu and rhyme, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary (plant).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking the guiding question, What do all plants need?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions about story elements; Identify the role of author and illustrator.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Blend onset and rime.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Distinguish words that sound similar but have different meanings.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children recognize the letters Dd, Uu, Gg.
Guide children as they blend onset and rime to form a familiar one syllable word and locate the picture.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help plants grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What plants do you see in the book you are reading?
What would you use to dig little pretend holes for planting seeds?
Draw some plants. How many plants did you draw? Write that number on the picture.
What place in this room would be a good place to grow a plant?
What materials would you use to make a little plant?
Point to the g in the word ground. Can you write uppercase and lowercase Gg?
What could you use from this center to make a pretend plant?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the ask and answer questions Mind Builder and introduce vocabulary (ask questions).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Anywhere Farm .
Read closely to notice and talk about how the author asks and answers questions about plants.
Offer an extended play activity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions about story elements; Identify the role of author and illustrator.
Blend onset and rime.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experience.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Introduce a guessing activity.
Have children ask questions to help them figure out which vegetable is hidden in the bag.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help plants grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Does the book you are reading have any plants or animals in it?
Can you show me how you could pretend to be a seed, a sprout, and a tall plant?
Collect some cubes. Pretend they are seeds. Can you tell me how many you have?
Can you make a list of things you need to plant an anywhere farm?
Can you show me the materials that you would use to make a huge plant?
I’ll write the word dig. Can you point to the letter that makes the /d/ sound?
Can you use blocks to build an anywhere farm?

Illustrations copyright © 2017 by G. Brian Karas. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build Earth Science background, have children plant a seed, and introduce vocabulary (soil, sprout).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Anywhere Farm and asking the guiding question: Where can plants grow?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions about story elements; Identify the role of author and illustrator.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Blend onset and rime.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.
Show understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Use and identify different digital tools.
Use digital tools safely.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Encourage children to think about the roles of buyer and seller.
Help children act as buyers and sellers.
Guide children to understanding that money is used to buy things.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help plants grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How does the book that you are reading right now help you think about plants?
Why would you need help if you wanted to use the Internet to learn more about vegetables?
Look at some seeds. How will they look after they grow?
How does a butterfly act when it comes to visit a vegetable farm?
How would you use construction paper to make paper vegetables?
Can you find letters D, G, and U? Can you name their sounds?
Can you show me how you can use these materials to make rows in a vegetable garden?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas:Jack and the Beanstalk

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about fairy tales, reality and fantasy, and introduce vocabulary (beanstalk, climbed).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Jack and the Beanstalk to Anywhere Farm .
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question: How can we help plants grow?
Offer an extended play activity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Write for different purposes.
Blend onset and rime.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Understand and use a growing number of prepositions.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children use prepositions to describe the location of different pretend foods.
Encourage children to expand their understanding and use of prepositions.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help plants grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Is the book you are listening to about things that are real or make-believe?
If you wanted to read a fairy tale on the Internet how would you ask for help from a grown-up?
Draw a beanstalk. Measure with connecting cubes. How tall is it?
Think about a funny place to plant vegetables. Where would that be?
Paint a picture of one leaf and a smaller or larger leaf.
What is the first letter in the word down? What sound does it make?
Can you make two sprouts with clay and compare them?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Anywhere Farm by Phyllis Root, illustrated by G. Brian Karas. Text copyright © 2017 by Phyllis Root. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by G. Brian Karas. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: box (Pavel Hlystov), paper roll (nuwatphoto).

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to engage children in reciting garden nursery rhymes, and introduce vocabulary (tenderly).
Begin Story Time by asking the guiding question: How can we help plants stay healthy?
Read and retell interactively.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat the details in a text; Identify the role of author and illustrator.
Identify rhyming words.
Write for different purposes.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s writing prompt: Write about how to help plants grow.
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help plants grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Is the book you are reading like Anywhere Farm? How it is the same or different?
Pretend you have vegetables to sell. How would you create a farmers’ market?
Use cubes to create three plants of different sizes. Which is the tallest? Which is the shortest?
Imagine an anywhere farm in your shoe. Would it be fun to have that?
Can you make up names for new kinds of vegetables?
Can you read an Alphabet Book with a friend?
Can you create a container that could be used to raise plants for an anywhere farm?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Blend onset (initial consonant or consonants) and rime (vowel to end) to form a familiar one syllable word with and without pictorial support.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Perceive differences between similar sounding words.
Observe, investigate, describe and discuss earth materials, and their properties and uses.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Blend onset (initial consonant or consonants) and rime (vowel to end) to form a familiar one syllable word with and without pictorial support.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Observe, investigate, describe and discuss earth materials, and their properties and uses.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Blend onset (initial consonant or consonants) and rime (vowel to end) to form a familiar one syllable word with and without pictorial support.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Observe, investigate, describe and discuss earth materials, and their properties and uses.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Use, operate, and name a variety of digital tools.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Blend onset (initial consonant or consonants) and rime (vowel to end) to form a familiar one syllable word with and without pictorial support.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Observe, investigate, describe and discuss earth materials, and their properties and uses.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Recognize rhyming words.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Observe, investigate, describe and discuss earth materials, and their properties and uses.
